text.p: Stocks fell on corporate earnings jitters Tuesday and bond prices lost ground after the Treasury sold $18 billion of new notes. The dollar also fell.
Gasoline prices jumped on a refinery outage in Venezuela but crude oil ended lower.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.07 points to close at 6,061.80 as investors sold technology companies after Digital Equipment Corp. reported a bigger-than-expected loss.
The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology issues, lost 16.41 points to 1,220.00, a much bigger percentage loss than the 30-share Dow industrials.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances 1,513 to 909 on active volume of 410 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

"The market has run out of steam," said Hildegard Zagorski, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "Yesterday was the tip-off when IBM had good earnings and the stock rocketed up and then fell apart. Then we had Microsoft. Not helping today was Digital with its big loss."
Digital reported a loss of $66 million in its fiscal first quarter, which disappointed Wall Street. Microsoft Corp.'s earnings of $614 million, while solid, were not as high as expected.

"A lot of technology earnings have met expectations and in some cases were better than expected," said Peter Cardillo, director of research of Westfalia Investments. "But that's already in the price. Profit-taking will continue for the next week or so right into the U.S. elections," he added.
Digital slumped $5.375 to $29 on the NYSE, and Microsoft lost $1.50 to $132.50 on Nasdaq.
"A lot of damage was done in Nasdaq today," said Ralph Bloch, chief technical analyst at Raymond James.
But the market was ripe for a correction after a swift rebound from the decline from May into July, he said. "The market has used up an incredible amount of firepower from the mid-July low."
The Nasdaq index has jumped 15.8 percent since bottoming in July, and the Dow index is up 13 percent.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury fell 20/32, or $6.25 on a $1,000 bond, to yield 6.86 percent compared with 6.81 percent on Monday.
The Treasury's sale of $18.28 billion in two-year notes produced encouraging results, but dealers said there was little buying in the auction's aftermath.
The dollar ended lower against major currencies as late selling wiped out modest early gains.
The dollar fell to 112.27 Japanese yen from 112.72 late on Monday. Against the German mark, the dollar fell nearly a pfennig to 1.5248 from 1.5343 late on Monday.
In commodity markets, gasoline surged after a big Venezuelan refinery suffered a partial outage.
Gasoline for November delivery rose 1.20 cents to 69.12 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
November crude oil fell 17 cents to $25.75 a barrel.
Overseas, London's FTSE 100 index fell 15.9 points to 4,057.2. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 closed at 21,123.68, down 179.27 points.
